quoteFirst: In July, the Queen and Prince took to their yacht again, for a visit to the Emperor and Empress, at Cherbourg, and had a grand reception, and there was a great _fête_, and fireworks and bombs and rockets; but the account is not half so interesting to me as the one given by Her Majesty, of their return to Osborne; an exquisite picture that, which I feel I must reproduce almost entire: ... "At
quoteLast: , we landed at our peaceful Osborne. ... The evening was very warm and calm. Dear Affie was on the pier, and we found all the other children, including Baby, standing at the door.
title: Queen Victoria, her girlhood and womanhood
author: Greenwood, Grace, 1823-1904

quoteFirst: A flight in some respects even more interesting than that of Mr. Curtiss was accomplished in France on the ninth of June, 1910, by Lieutenant Feguant and Captain Marconnet, officers of the French army, on a Farman bi-plane. "Starting from Chalons at
quoteLast: ," says the _Scientific American_, "the officers flew 176 kilometers (109¼ miles) across country to the artillery park at Vincennes, which was reached at 7:10. This flight of two and one-half hours' duration was accomplished at a speed of 43¾ miles per hour.
title: Every-day Science: Volume 7. The Conquest of Time and Space
author: Williams, Henry Smith, 1863-1943; Williams, Edward Huntington, 1868-1944

quoteLast: he landed once more amongst Mr. Dodge’s swedes.
title: The golden windmill, and other stories

quoteFirst: Infantry outpost on the drift. Firing was heard at
quoteLast: on the north-west, and subsequently it was found that a patrol going out from the southerly piquet, furnished by the Devonshire Imperial Yeomanry, had been attacked. Then closer and closer came the enemy upon the Yeomanry piquet. Every gallant fellow dropped.
title:
South Africa and the Transvaal War, Vol. 7 (of 8)
The Guerilla War, from February 1901 to the Conclusion of Hostilities
author: Creswicke, Louis

quoteFirst: Lowder's reply to Densher's note had been to appoint the tea-hour, five o'clock on Sunday, for his seeing them. Kate had thereafter wired him, without a signature, "Come on Sunday _before_ tea--about a quarter of an hour, which will help us"; and he had arrived therefore scrupulously at
quoteLast: . Kate was alone in the room and hadn't delayed to tell him that Aunt Maud, as she had happily gathered, was to be, for the interval--not long but precious--engaged with an old servant, retired and pensioned, who had been paying her a visit and who was within the hour to depart again for the suburbs.
title: The Wings of the Dove, Volume II
author: James, Henry, 1843-1916

quoteFirst: Ducks.--At Tarbet Ness a large flock of ducks passed inland at 10 a.m., with a N. gale and snow, on Nov. 12th. At Girdleness, two ducks seen at
quoteLast: , wind S.W., and haze, on Oct. 16th. At Tarbet Ness a large flock seen at 9.15 a.m., wind W., strong and snow, on Dec. 5th. At Dunnet Head seven ducks (Widgeon) stayed on the lake three days from Oct. 25th; arrived with W. to N.W. breeze and cloudy.
title: Report on the Migration of Birds in the Autumn of 1879. [First Report]
author: Harvie-Brown, J. A. (John Alexander), 1844-1916; Cordeaux, John, 1831-1899
